Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Integration of carbohydrate and gaseous fermentations for maximum C3 and C4 chemical yield
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project is to develop renewable and domestic chemical production and transportation fuel technologies that are cheaper, greener and more sustainable. Additionally, chemical companies are constantly looking for ways to improve business sustainability by reducing carbon footprints along with cost of manufacturing. Mixotrophic fermentation can be a step-change improvement in microbial fermentation for the production of numerous intermediate and commodity chemicals. Yields from feedstock can be increased substantially, and CO2 gas produced from the fermentation, as a waste byproduct can instead be captured and assimilated into valuable chemicals, which translates into a significant improvement in yield and productivity for any applicable commodity or intermediate chemical production process. Consequently, the commercial and environmental implications of this innovative technological approach are tremendous. Furthermore, this project could significantly enhance scientific and technological understanding of microbial physiology and metabolism during gas and carbohydrate fermentation.

The objectives of this Phase II research project are to develop and scale-up platform strains for C3 and C4 chemical production using carbon efficient pathways. The approach being developed is referred to as Anaerobic Non-Photosynthetic (ANP) mixotrophic fermentation, and process advancements will focus on bioreactor operation parameters, media formulations, and integration with product separation. By the end of this project, the project will likely have demonstrated and validated enhanced mass yield of C3 and/or C4 metabolite production at pilot-scale using ANP mixotrophic fermentation.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project entitled Integration of carbohydrate and gaseous fermentations for maximum C3 and C4 chemical yield aimed to expand upon the concept of concurrent carbohydrate and gas utilization (termed ANP mixotrophy) and undertake development work to scale-up this process. In order to realize the most cost effective fermentation for commodity and intermediate chemical production, the process must obtain maximum conversion of feedstock to chemical of interest (i.e., yield). In all carbohydrate fermentations, CO2 is always and H2 is commonly evolved. Subsequently, yield of feedstock is reduced. However, that loss can be recaptured by ANP mixotrophic fermentation. ANP mixotrophic fermentation is the simultaneous consumption of organic and inorganic substrates, such as glucose and the evolved CO2 and H2. The improvement in yield due to mixotrophic fermentation can be very significant. During Phase I, we demonstrated both the feasibility and the mass yield benefits of ANP mixotrophy. Therefore, during Phase II, we are focused on development of platform strains and in developing the fermentation setup (both bioreactor design and medium optimization). Through these efforts, we were able to produce C3 and C4 chemicals with enhanced mass yields

 Broader/Commercial Impact

It is of major importance to the United States to develop renewable and domestic chemical production and transportation fuel technologies. Additionally, chemical companies are constantly looking for ways to improve business sustainability by reducing carbon footprints along with cost of manufacturing. Mixotrophic fermentation can be a step-change improvement in microbial fermentation for the production of numerous intermediate and commodity chemicals. Yields of feedstock can be increased 10 – 50%, and all CO2 gas from the entire process can be captured and assimilated into valuable chemicals, which translates into a 10 – 50% reduction in operating expenses for any commodity or intermediate chemical production process. Consequently, the commercial and environmental implications are tremendous. We successfully demonstrated at varying scales (50mL - 1000L) the ability to produce C2, C3 and C4 chemicals at new theoretical maximum yields.  Moreover, we improve the carbohydrate substrate utilization of these unique microorganisms and invented and demonstrated a highly productive fermentation system that can be relevant to the production of many different biochemicals.  Overall, this project established a foundation for combining the strengths of US agricultural and fossil feedstocks for enhanced energy and chemical independence.


Last Modified: 02/27/2018
Modified by: Bryan P Tracy

Moreover, we improve the carbohydrate substrate utilization of these unique microorganisms and invented and demonstrated a highly productive fermentation system that can be relevant to the production of many different biochemicals.
